columns.text: In this exercise, we will determine which of the two athletes has a better deal in their contract.

**Athlete 1 got the better deal**

In this type of analysis, it's always important to consider the inflation factor. The value of the money decreases as time passes; therefore, it is always desirable to take the money earlier rather than prolong the payment or at a slower phase. Hence, the first athletes with the ten-year equal installment have a better deal.

In the case of the second athlete wherein, there is a rate component in the installment; this will result in a lower present value when compared to the first athlete. The relation of rate on the present value is that the higher the discount rate, the lower the preset value will be as the rate is divided by the cashflows per period.

To summarize, we determined that the first athlete has a better deal than the second athlete by considering the present value of their payments. The ten equal installments are better over ten increasing installments.

As the athlete 1 gets equal installments, it's evident that all of his installments will be (values in millions):

$$\text{Installment Amount}=\frac{\$80}{10}=\$8$$

The first athlete will have $8 million guaranteed every payout.

Second athlete meanwhile has ever increasing payments. Even without calculations, we can infer how this athlete's payment will go out.

We know it has to cap at $80 million, and that payouts have to keep increasing. If initial payment is $x$, next payment is $y$, where $y=+5\%$ (this is just at base value, without the present value calculations, which are also trickier as the payouts are defined as equally periodic).

This tells us that initial payments have to start smaller, and keep increasing to the point where their net sum will be $80 million.

Just from this comparison, we can determine that **first athlete got the better deal**.

Even though at some point individual payouts of the second athlete are likely to exceed the payout of first athlete, the first athlete will have constant sums paid out and will know what money will he always have at his disposal, the second athlete will have to contend with smaller amounts first until they reach higher (and more desirable) numbers.
